completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: Nice change from the traditional format.  I would call it Big Bang meets Scooby Doo while channeling Numbers.  Don't get me wrong that is not a bad thing.  A retired educator and IT pro I enjoyed the book tremendously.  Yes it was apparent this was a departure for this author but it works.I found the characters engaging and can see a long running series for this heroine.  The father of two geeks and a bit of a geek myself I could relate to the characters.  I can also see how some would have problems doing so.  However, you have to remember that some suspension of reality is necessary for most mysteries to work.  Additionally most authors are distilling down characters that a mix of many different people they know or have observed.  Having worked with and managed many people of Lexi's type I think she came up with an entertaining and engaging mash up.The book is also light and humorous a real plus for me.  I lifelong devourer of books I have given up on the heavy and the dark which seems to prevail in Science Fiction and many genres of the thrillers of today.  I read for a laugh and for relaxation.  If I want to be depressed I will read the paper.  Just enough suspense to keep it interesting and just enough humor to keep it light.So bottom line if you have a little geek in you male or female and you like a good laugh check out this series.

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewerName: Ginny - Gin's Book Notes "Book blogger at Gin...
completeRevs.summary: Three word review: fun, smart, adventure
completeRevs.reviewText: I really enjoyed "No One Lives Twice" book 1 in Julie Moffett's, Lexi Carmichael Mystery series.  I picked it up during a free promotion but it is one that I would have felt I got my money's worth from if I had purchased it. As a matter of fact, I've already purchased book 2 and hope to be able to read it soon.Lexi Carmichael is a NSA computer geek. She is super smart but a little lacking in common sense and at times socially awkward. I loved her. There were moments that I laughed at her and moments that I cringed and thought "no, no, Lexi don't do that".I loved that the author balanced out all Lexi's quirks so that nothing was over the top. You get the good and the bad and in the end you end up wanting to cheer for Lexi and give her a mini-makeover while at the same time encouraging her to stay true to herself.The mystery aspects of the story are great. There is a touch of James Bond type adventure to the story that moves things along at a fast pace. There's some romance but it's more hints of things to come as the series progresses type romance.At the end the mystery is solved and Lexi is left with possibilities of future employment and romance. This is a series that I am looking forward to reading and following as Lexi and her fellow characters solve more mysteries and find romance.Three word review: fun, smart, adventure

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: Lexi Carmichael is a geek, a computer geek to be specific, and works for the NSA. She has no love life to speak of, and doesn't find herself to be very appealing to men. But now her best friend Basia has disappeared and men seem to be lining up to help find her.I loved the action in this story. It was fast paced and exciting. It was great to see a bunch of computer geeks in action to save the day. In fact, the computer geeks were my favorite part...except for Lexi. Now since Lexi is our main character, that poses quite a predicament. Lexi is just a little too depressing. She complains about her lack of love life, her lack of taste in clothes, and about anyone who tries to help her. She gets a bit annoying at times just because she is always talking herself down.The action, on the other hand, is fantastic. There are so many twists and turns subtly worked into the story, and they kept me guessing up until the very end.3/5

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: Lexi is a witty and engaging female character. I loved the story line which was filled with mystery, suspense and romance. The male lead characters were captivating. It is a gifted author who  has her readers rooting for Lexi to end up with any of the men because she portrays them  all with style, humor and a touch of humanity. Although I do have a slight preference for one of the men. I know I will be reading more Lexi Carmichael mysteries in order to solve the mystery of  who she end up with -  Slash, Finn or Elvis.

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: The first book in the Lexi Carmichael Mystery Series.  I had been putting this off since I lumped it into the Stephanie Plum and Brandy Alexander category.  This book is VERY similar to those series.  I do find the Janet Evanovich books much more humorous, but I like the character of Lexi a bit better than Stephanie.  Maybe because Lexi is smarter.  I know I will eventually tire of a possible love triangle.  The author set it up quite clearly and they are almost clones of Ranger and Morelli.  I do recommend this book and will keep reading them unless they start getting too predictable and/or dragging out the same story line.  I have to say, as much as I love the Stephanie Plum books (I'm a huge fan and recommended them to many friends) I haven't read one since 12 or 13.  Couldn't take them any more, no growth or decisions were ever made.  I am hopeful Julie Moffett won't let that happen here.

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: Heh. Geek girl gets thrown in the middle of international craziness and finds her social life taking off when all the men around her are of the hunky variety. I CAN GET BEHIND THIS IDEA!First off, Lexi goes from having a dating life that's a social wasteland to drowning in hot, smart, sexy men. Sure, most of them are keeping secrets from her and she's understandably upset about it when she finds out but the man-candy parade seems well worth it to me. On the other hand, having your life threatened and getting shot at a time or two don't seem as fun. But Lexi takes it in stride. She has the occasional meltdown (and who wouldn't!?!) but when she starts to understand what sort of shenanigans her best friend has been unintentionally dragged into, she rallies and starts plotting and planning.With the sexy hacker guys. *slow thumbs up*I was in the mood for something fast-paced and fun and this book delivered. Lexi is pretty clueless when it comes to men but that doesn't stop the hunks from gathering. She's good with computers, but has no field experience and she's smart enough to play to her strengths. I like a girl with smarts. I also like a girl who goes out and buys news clothes when she can't stomach the idea of doing laundry. Oh, Lexi. Don't ever change.-Kelly @ Reading the Paranormal

completeRevs.reviewText: I really, really, really enjoyed this book!!! There are several reasons why. The first is the fact that the heroine is not beautiful and rich with a jaw dropping body. She's very smart but that isn't thrown out there constantly making those of us, whose math/computer skills are less than stellar, feel inadequate. completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.summary: An Okay Start to New Mystery Series
completeRevs.reviewText: No One Lives Twice is a fun and wild adventure of an unsuspecting geek thrown into the crazy world of espionage, but be prepared for a few bumps in the road with this novel. Still, that's no reason you shouldn't pull up a chair, grab a shaken martini and prepare yourself for Lexi Carmichael...the female James Bond!Lexi Carmichael was having your average boring and uneventful day when she was confronted in the street by a mad man with a gun. He demands Lexi had over a document she has no knowledge of. Confused and terrified, Lexi arrives at her apartment only to discover her best friend Basia did send her papers with a note that she keep them safe. Knowing there is something deeper behind these papers, Lexi is determined to get to the bottom of this puzzle. With the help of her computer-hacking friends Lexi is working desperately to help Basia. The more she discovers about Basia's secret, the deeper she becomes entangled in this dangerous web. Now all Lexi needs is a plan...and a miracle.Moffett pens a delightful and exciting adventure for this simple computer geek gone rouge. Perhaps my favorite part of this first person novel were the secondary characters. No One Lives Twice has a wide range of fun and wacky characters that will make you smile and laugh. These characters mean business, but yet there is a light and funny side in their complimentary relationship when they work together. I could easily see fans of the Stephanie Plum series really enjoying this story and all it's eclectic characters. It has that same sexy edge, with a bit of light humor and fascinating characters to keep readings intrigued.Moffett adds plenty of sexy book candy to this novel, all setting their eyes on Lexi. Yet despite the lightness of this novel, one problem was the revolving door of potential romantic candidates. It was incredibly difficult, if not impossible, to believe that a woman with such a dry and uneventful romantic life was turning the heads of every male character in this story (and I literally mean every male character). I wanted to see one character pushed to front as the guy she was most interested in, even if everyone else was still chasing her around. If was hinted at the end, but not enough to be convincing. Usually with any love triangle, or in this case love pentagon, the reader can claim their favorite. It wasn't so in this case and that took a little of the joy out of the overall story.Another teeny tiny problem was the overwhelming description and drawn out plot points. By the third chapter, I think I read about Lexi stopping at every fast food joint known to man, and what she ate there. Admittedly, there was some unwanted detail, but the novel was still a fresh and fun read. Lexi is a great character with a lot of spunk and charm! The storyline is definitely unpredictable as you follow along with Lexi to solve the case and rescue her friend. Moffett takes her original characters on a thrilling ride that most girls only dream of! No One Lives Twice is an entertaining and fun novel for anyone who enjoys seeing the underdog computer geek come out of her shell to save the day. This novel is a decent start to a fresh new series. With a few slight modifications, this series could be flat out fantastic.Overall Rating: 3/5Heat Level: 1/5Lisa @ Once Upon A Chapter

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.summary: Stephanie Plum,  Lisbeth Salander, and James Bond in One
completeRevs.reviewText: This was a fun book. Think 1/3 Stephanie Plum, 1/3 Lisbeth Salander, and 1/3 James Bond.Lexi is a 24 going on 25 year old woman with a top secret computer job. She is a computer geek, wears no makeup, has had sex exactly one time in her life, and it is quite possible that she buys her clothes at Walmart. Not what you picture as a Bond girl... She also loves Dunkin Donuts and Diet Coke. She is very down to earth, sassy, and honest. She does not have a side kick named Lulu, but there are hot guys suddenly popping out of the woodwork and just appearing in her apartment at all hours of the day and night. Unfortuneately, Lexi can trust none of them.From computer geek to Bond girl.. After being abducted twice in one night, interrogated about some papers she was supposed to have received in the mail, and discovering her best friend has gone missing, Lexi starts asking questions. Before you know it, she is shot at and uncovering some major corruption involving a fertility clinic and 40 million dollars and an Arab prince. A hot Irish lawyer, a sexy Swede karate instructor, and an Enrique Inglesius look alike all claim to want to help Lexi get to the bottom of this mess, but each one is hiding secrets of his own. Who can she trust?There are hot kisses, agents on stakeouts, world traveling, handcuffs, and another sexy guy named Elvis. I wonder if this is the beginning of a series? I can see it going somewhere. I had a few chuckles and a whole lot of fun wondering what mess Lexi was going to end up in next.Why not five whole stars? Too much information and too many characters at times. Still, a fun read tho.

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: This is the first romance book that I've read, involving computer hackers and it really didn't disappoint! Not only was it fun, but it was also extremely witty, humorous, non-predictable, and action-filled. There were honestly no dull moments in that book and it was all I could do NOT to put the book down. The interesting men in Lexi Carmichael's life really intrigued me also which made me look forward to the next installment in the series. The fact that I can completely identify and emphasize with such a realistic character is an added bonus to liking the book. There are a lot of interesting twists and turns in the book, so be prepared for a wonderful, intriguing ride. Highly recommended.

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: Solid 4.5 stars. I really enjoyed this fun romp. Shades of Stephanie Plumb, well written, and a story I found myself picking up throughout the day and reading with a smile. I wish we could have seen more of Lexi's computer skills and maybe relying more on her brothers than her friends and strangers who popped somewhat suspiciously into her life during this adventure. I mean, why give her brothers awesome, story-apropriate-and-intriguing jobs like a cop and an investigative reporter and then not really use them? Maybe in the next books of the series, which I will definitely purchase. Had a lot of lighthearted fun reading this one.

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: I'm officially in love with Lexi!!! Julie Moffett writes like I'm living and experiencing what Lexi does. I have a new favorite author to follow!! I recommend this book and her other two in the series to date!

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: I accidentally requested book 2 of this series from netGalley, so I found myself in a position to find and read book 1 first because I don't enjoy reading books out of order.This was my first Moffett read, and I really enjoyed it!  It had a very easy flow, which made it a quick, light read.  I enjoy Lexi's character - she is that geeky yet sexy girl, in a bookish subtle sort of way.  I don't even think she knows yet what kind of power she has over certain men.  Just because she doesn't like her figure, doesn't mean men don't find her attractive.  They obviously do if this book is any indication.  3 guys swooning over her the entire book without any sort of encouragement on her part is pretty funny.At first, I had no idea what sort of investigative trouble Lexi was getting herself into, and the story kept taking twists and turns into different directions until I was so confused that it wasn't until the ending two chapters that I finally understood the complexity of the situation she was in and the part that everyone played in the whole operation. Elvis and Xavier are absolutely hilariously brilliant, and a great team to have on your side when dealing with several governmental agencies - FBI, CIA, NSA, MI-6 and the Vatican Intelligence.  When Lexi gets herself thrown into a situation, she really gets involved deep!Slash is an unknown quantity, and I can't help but wonder what role he will play as the series continues - but he is definitely sexy!!  Basia is fiercely loyal and that's a great quality to have in a best friend...even one who involves you in something you really don't want to be involved in.  Finn is sexy, in that Irish sort of way, but still a bit of an enigma.  It'll be interesting to see how his and Lexi's "relationship" evolves in books to come.  The ending was pretty good, and I think Lexi is about to embark on a totally different career path than a lowly computer geek at the NSA.  I can't wait to read more!

completeRevs.title: No One Lives Twice
completeRevs.reviewText: In the space of a few hours Lexi Carmichael went from her dull job stopping hackers with the National Security Agency to being confronted with two different gun-wIelding thugs. Why? Because everyone seems to be looking for her best friend and some mysterious papers that she might have sent.  Lexi is totally confused since normally her biggest threat is the blind dates her mother keeps setting up for her.  Lexi knows and accepts she is a dull, brainy geek with little interest in fashion but her mother still tries to set her up with men who don't know how to handle her.Trying to find her friend and discover what everyone else is trying to find, Lexi goes to her other best friends, Elvis and Xavier Zimmerman, twins who are genius with computers and have designed extremely sensitive electronic networks.  You would think that would be enough but no, now Lexi is confronted with one sexy Italian government agent co-named Slash, who says he will help her, and a drop-dead handsome Irish man named Finn Shaughnessy who was working with the missing friend when everything went down.  Lexi now has to not only find her friend and keep her safe, figure out who is behind the thugs, and work her way though feelings for two men who normally would never look twice at her but seem to be falling for Lexi.  With a madcap plan, Lexi works her way from Jersey to Sweden with a trail of thugs, thieves, Finn, Slash and friends all to save the day and get to the bottom of what is going on and why.Thugs, Guns and Hot Guys - Oh my.  No One Lives Twice takes a geeky Lexi out of her normal life and puts her in the middle of an international who-dun-it.  I knew I would like Lexi from the first when I discovered she was a junk food junky and slow to get her laundry done.  When I then got thrown Slash, Finn and a mystery that is turning deadly, I knew this was going to be one fun book.  I was not wrong.  Watching as Lexi dealt with two gun-toting thugs, two beyond smart computer geniuses, one hot agent and then a toe-curling lawyer, all while trying to find and help a friend, proved to be a page turning plot.  I loved the humor that was the background for everything. The beginning buds of romance Lexi was feeling with both Slash and Finn at separate times had me wondering if Lexi would be able to choose. I can't wait until the next Lexi book so I can see just how her life has changed and who will get the upper hand in the romance department - Slash or Finn.  No One Lives Twice is a humorous look at the world of secret agents and enemy plots that will become an instant favorite series.JoReviewed for Joyfully Reviewed

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I need to admit it openly: I'm addicted to Josh Lanyon.His writing is so good that you're never even aware of the author writing. It's virtually cinematic. I'm not sure exactly what he does to effect this, but each page is so alive and present that even the dull ones, when nothing much is happening, are interesting and engaging.That's the word: "engaging". His characters, locations, plots, exposition and dialog are all engaging. They grab you from the first word on the first page and don't let go until the ending. The plot, like this one about a serial killer, doesn't even have to be mind-grabbingly unique. In fact, the plot of "Fair Game" is a perfectly standard serial killer mystery/police procedural. But in the hands of the master writer, it becomes so real, so alive, that you can't bear to walk away from it until you get to the very last page.This applies not just to "Fair Game", but to the six or seven other Lanyon novels to which I've also given enthusiastic 5-star reviews. This is not a fluke. It is the sign of a genuine talent, and Mr. Lanyon is, at very least, a most genuine talent.

But something odd is going on,  and this brings Tucker Lance,  FBI agent,  back into  Elliot's life.I enjoyed the mystery,  but I really loved the dynamic between Elliot and Tucker,  how they misunderstood each other and let each other down after the terrible shooting and then struggled back to a kind of friendship and then something more.I rate this a keeper and a reread,  and while not as gripping as Adrien English (well,  I haven't read 5 books with them yet,  give it a chance...) and I for one would be delighted to meet these characters again.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: 4 1/2 Elliot is a former FBI agent, injured on the job, and now reluctantly working as history professor due to his bum knee. He doesn't realize just how much he misses his old life until he gets involved in a missing person investigation and finds himself consultant to the FBI and his ex-lover Tucker. Their relationship simply ended when Elliot was injured and neither has ever resolved it. Seeing each other is drudging up uncomfortable memories for Elliot, who insists the two had nothing in common anyway. Except sex. Mindblowing sex. Elliot really misses the sex. Tucker apparently was very good at it.This is a mystery with solid writing and strong sense of place. The romance is there, slowly building in the background but it's first and foremost an intriguing murder mystery. I wasn't expecting that because I've probably been reading way too many m/m erotica novels. I've gotten comfy with the main focus being (often) 100% on the relationship, the sexing and the conflicts within that relationship. Fair Game follows its own path and was a nice surprise.Tucker doesn't welcome Elliot's interference on the case and isn't at all shy about letting him know it. Working together is difficult for them; they have unresolved, unsaid stuff between them. Stuff neither wants to talk about. Both are resentful and have feelings of abandonment but talking would mean facing their feelings and these guys aren't the type to have a big emotional row.Elliot and Tucker seem like men most of us know (albeit probably much better looking). They think like guys, they act like guys and it was such a nice change of pace for me, having read more than my fair share of books that featured gay men who were, ahem, so fem and saccharine sweet I felt as if I were reading a fairy tale or someone's idea of a dream man. Fair Game seemed less of a fantasy and more of a reality about two tough, stubborn men who have a connection and whether they're willing to admit it or not want each other but can't communicate. Instead they brood and let things simmer until it all spills out in the form of hot kisses and near sex. It was so real it was touching. Seriously, who doesn't know a man afraid to talk about what he's feeling and would much prefer to clam up and get naked?I'm not a big mystery girl but this one never had me daydreaming or wishing I was reading something, anything, else. It was interesting; the characters well developed and there were more than enough suspects to keep me guessing and, yeah, the romance was lovely. If I didn't have so many other books to read right now and a crazy busy weekend I would snatch up the rest of Lanyon's work and hide away in my room until I'd read myself into a stupor.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: Beautiful story of a man in transition
completeRevs.reviewText: Landry's Review at Mrs Condit & Friends review blog: “Fair Game” tells the tale of Elliot Mills, a man in transition. He used to be a top FBI agent in the Pacific Northwest until an on-the-job injury forced him to start over as a college history professor in his Washington state hometown. Everything is new for him but not much is necessarily better. He likes teaching and loves being near his dad-his only remaining relative- but being an agent for the Bureau was his dream career and he was good at it. When a gunshot wound forced him out of field work, he knew he was not suited for a desk job. So he walked away from that life and everyone who was a part of it—-and that included fellow agent and new lover Tucker Lance.Elliot was just learning to accept his new, quieter life when he reluctantly agreed to his father’s request to help old family friends search for their missing son, a student at the college where he taught. Elliot is drawn deeper into the case when he realizes that they are more victims involved. Soon the FBI is called in and Elliot is forced to swallow a lot of personal issues and deal with his old flame, Special Agent Lance. I know this book is about the mystery Elliot and Tucker are brought together to solve. But, personally, I found it more interesting to uncover and understand the whole story behind the prior romance that the two main characters shared before Elliot’s injury. Telling this personal story did not happen fast. In fact, because so little was explained in the beginning of the book, I originally thought that this was a later installment in a series. I checked and it wasn’t. This was simply the author’s choice to slowly let us, the readers, in on the exact nature of their relationship, how it developed and eventually fell apart. It caught and held my interest because I wanted to know! But, honestly, I would have liked to know more sooner. Knowing the back story helped me to understand and like Tucker so much more. It also made it easier to relate to Elliot even if I did not always agree with the choices he made. He certainly has what it takes to be a top-notch cop. He was always a step ahead of everyone else, except of course the perpetrator, at least until the very end. Elliot figured out “whodunit” but in my eyes, it was the tiniest piece of evidence possible that lead him to identify the guilty party. Still, the crime wave was stopped and Elliot and Tucker had time to talk and come to a new understanding. I enjoyed author Josh Lanyon’s descriptive writing skills. His words created beautiful visions of the Washington State area. I could picture the scenery but I did have to check a state map to understand the distance between the different locations he mentioned. There were many characters introduced but I was disappointed that we didn’t learn much about the victims, especially the first young man Elliot was asked to help find. I didn’t feel any real personal sympathies for him, no sense of loss because he was really just a name, not a person. There were several possible suspects discussed and when the culprit was revealed, it was not the person I first suspected so, as a mystery, the story worked fine for me. This mystery seemed to be the main focus of the book but it was the romance between Elliot and Tucker that I enjoyed the most. Having the two men come together and work out their differences was the outcome I most anticipated and in the end, I was rewarded.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: I found one of the main guys a little hard to like, but the book has a great action/mystery plot
completeRevs.reviewText: Warning: This review might contain what some people consider SPOILERS.Rating: 8/10PROS:- I found the plot interested and well-paced. The mystery is...mysterious (at least, *I* didn't guess the murderer's identity before it was revealed, although I'm admittedly not a great mystery solver), and the story incorporates a lot of different witnesses presenting differing views on the case and widely disparate opinions about the other people involved--all of which Elliot and Tucker have to sift through to discover the truth.- The characters are interesting while at the same time seeming like real people. None of them have the "perfect" feel of fictional characters; Elliot and Tucker both act like real men with believable insecurities and fairly quick tempers. I also like that there's no power inequality in their relationship: they're equally strong and intelligent.- Lanyon does an excellent job of reinforcing character traits, especially those that reveal something about the character's past. There's a little indication nearly every page early on in the story that Elliot's current life as a professor is quite different from his former life working for the FBI.- I used to teach college English, and Elliot strikes me as a true-to-life depiction of a college professor. He's intelligent and a little careless, he interacts with his students as though he's equal parts amused and frightened by them, and he thinks of them by first and last name, often inverted ("Mrachek, Leslie"). The story also contains a large number of caustic remarks about the arrogance of people who work in academia (example: "Only in academia did people talk such [b.s.] and expect to be taken seriously"). Not all academics are that way, of course--Elliot isn't; otherwise his observations wouldn't be funny--but the comments are largely true and made me laugh out loud more than once.CON:- The entire story is told in third person limited from Elliot's perspective. This isn't inherently a bad thing; this was just one of those stories that I really wanted to see from both main characters' points of view. Elliot has some pretty painful memories of Tucker, and I wanted to see Tucker's defense of himself. The main reason I wanted to see Tucker's perspective on their history together is that so many of their early encounters in this story are bitter and tight-lipped and angry. I could see Elliot's desire for something more to develop once again, but all I ever saw from Tucker was his outward terseness, so I started thinking of him as kind of a jerk. Tucker's redemptive moment, for me, didn't come until three-quarters of the way through the book.Overall comments: The plot, as opposed to the relationship, is certainly central here. But it's a good plot. I wasn't QUITE on the edge of my seat biting my fingernails the whole time, but I never lost interest, never wanted to put the book down. The investigation plot and the romance are also well tied together. It didn't feel to me as though either one was tacked on to the story as an afterthought.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I really enjoyed this, I do wish there had been more between Tucker and Elliot, and I don't just mean more sex--though that would have been nice, too, but I was craving a little more connection and interaction between the two.I think I accused just about everybody of something, I was right a few times and was surprised a time as well, so I enjoyed that.Would recommend and will read more from this author.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: So good it gave me brain freeze ;)
completeRevs.reviewText: I often wonder how 80% of the books out there get published. I think to myself, 'who read this and thought: I must get this out to the masses immediately'; I didn't wonder that once while reading this book. IT WAS EXCELLENT. It's the kind of writing that forces the reader to pay attention and even look up a few words or theological themes. It is very obvious the writer is intelligent, more obvious that he expects his readers to be. I like that; please don't dumb it down on my account; I love learning new words.Anyway, this story is first and foremost a mystery, not a romance as I had previously thought when considering it for purchase. Still, the relationship between Elliot and Tucker offers a much needed and equally engrossing subtext. Both the plot and the relationship milestones moved forward seamlessly and best of all I never felt like either dragged out to some inevitable conclusion, despite the foregone conclusion of a 'case closed and HEA' ending due to it's genre and reader preferences. That's hard to do these days. Bravo.I don't want to spoil any of the story by offering insights into the plot. Suffice to say,when the mood strikes and my brain cells need massaging I'll be sure to pick up another of Josh Lanyon's novels.And for those to wonder why I gave this book 4, instead of 5 stars: I only rate books at five stars if I can enjoy them more that once. With the mystery solved and the romance only secondary, I probably won't read this book again, unless of course I want to write down any of those ten cent words I had to look up the first time around. I don't know if that's fair, but it's true. Besides, Josh Lanyon doesn't need my 5 star review to write a 5 star mystery, nor does he need me to buoy his career. His work speaks eloquently enough for itself. READ IT!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I have recently fallen into love with Josh Lanyon's work. His stories are well crafted and his characters and plot have amazing depth. This book had everything I was looking for in a great story. Amazing characters, a well designed murder mystery, and hot steamy sex. The scene where Tucker comes to Elliots rescue at the lake was nail biting. I was literally at work and I couldn't put the story down until I knew they were alright. Thank god I didn't get fired. I found absolutley nothing to dislike about this book and I must say that I wish for a sequel most desperatly. I would love to know how the main characters are dealing with their new found relationship.Thank you Josh for another amazing story!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: Thanks for another sleepless night, Josh Lanyon! (Fist in air but smiling)
completeRevs.reviewText: Wow, I LOVED this story! The mystery/suspense portion was interesting & had me guessing- definitely not a throw-away as background to the romance portion. The MCs were fantastic. The story was written in 3rd person but from Elliot's POV, so you developed a more intimate 'relationship' w/ him vs Tucker, but it worked! Elliot was a sympathetic character and was very like-able. He & Tucker were fantastic together. They clearly cared for each other & had to work through old hurts to kick start the new version of their lives together. I liked that Tucker was a little more clued in & open about what he wanted. Elliot had more baggage to lose but I never felt that they were unreasonable in their dealings w/ each other. No gratuitous stupidity or conflict. Yay!I don't know how Josh Lanyon does it, but I've pretty much loved all of his MCs & their relationships. There is just the right amount of conflict, internal & external, the right amount of tenderness, & perfect sexy times. I really can't say enough. I've become a rabid devotee of Lanyon since I started reading his works a few weeks ago.Back to this story, it was both a mystery & romance, side-by-side. I think he nailed the secondary characters as well. No throw-aways here either. My ONLY ongoing Lanyon complaint. I would love to see an epilogue! For all of his stories. I always feel like I'm not ready to say goodbye yet when the stories end. It's not a bad complaint to have & is a testament to how good Lanyon is at what he does.I couldn't put the book down, but when I had to, I couldn't wait to get back to it (OK, I read it in a day, but still). Great emotional depth, interesting & sexy MCs, a solid supporting cast, what's not to love? This is probably one of my favorite Lanyon's to date.Highly recommend!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: Josh Lanyon is always good, and this one is terrific. It includes Lanyon's signature protagonist with some kind of disability in the form of Elliott. He was an FBI Agent who was injured in the line of duty and now teaches. A disappearance that turns into a series of disappearances at his school pulls him into a role investigating what's going on. Unfortunately, it also brings him back into contact with his former partner from the Bureau, Tucker. The man who he feels dropped out of his life completely once he was injured. It also makes him a target of the killer they are each hunting. Again, a fantastic book with an awesome plot, executed perfectly. I am SO glad Lanyon uses his powers for the good of m/m readers everywhere.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: It's strange since Carina Press is actually a romance publisher, but I think Fair Game is the less "romance" among the novels by Josh Lanyon I read; now, there is a love story in it, but really, the lion share in the plot is to the mystery/thriller. Elliot Mills, former FBI agent and currently a college professor, is investigating on the disappearance of a student, who happens to be a family friends's son. That former lover Tucker Lance is the FBI agent in charge of the investigation it's not a plus to Elliot's eyes.When I said the mystery is more important of the romance, I don't want to give the impression the romance is not good. I actually liked how real both Elliot than Tucker seemed; when Elliot was forced to leave the FBI, Tucker was not really sympathetic, and the reason was purely egoistic: Elliot leaving meant less chances for them to continue with their story, or also losing what little they had in common, aside for their job, Elliot and Tucker were at the opposite, and Tucker had the wrong idea only their job was bounding them. On the other hand, Elliot was stubborn, and not ready, or willingly, to listen to Tucker's explanation, once he realized what mistake he did. Elliot is a little of a primadonna, and being attacked by Tucker was something he didn't forgive easily; when he was down, he wanted for people to commiserate him, to tell him how unfair was the fate, that he didn't deserve it... he didn't want for someone else to be miserable, to steal his spotlight in hell, and Tucker was.But now, months later, both of them are ready to admit they were wrong, and while Tucker is able to say the words, Elliot perhaps prefers to prove them with facts; it's easier to commit with his body than with his words. Maybe since, words are harder to hide or deny.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: Above average and enjoyable.  Mostly mystery solving, some good action scenes and a few intense M/M sex scenes.
completeRevs.reviewText: FAIR GAME by Josh Lanyon.STORY BRIEF:Elliot and Tucker were FBI agents.  They had an intense sexual relationship for three months until Elliot was shot in the knee.  At that time they broke up.  (The reader doesn't know why until later in the book.)  It is now 17 months after their break-up.  Elliot has an artificial knee which restricts his movements, requires weekly therapy, and is painful at times.  Elliot didn't want a desk job with the FBI so he now teaches history at a university.  He misses Tucker.A student Terry is missing.  His parents are friends of Elliot's father.  They feel the police and FBI aren't doing enough and ask Elliot to look into the disappearance.  Tucker is the FBI agent in charge of the case.  Elliot and Tucker interact regarding the case.  A second student Gordie goes missing.  The university president asks Elliot to look into that as well.  Elliot suspects a serial killer.REVIEWER'S OPINION:This is mostly a mystery.  There is suspense because the killer knows Elliot is investigating and wants him dead.  There is not much relationship development between Elliot and Tucker.  Their interaction on the case is the catalyst for them to start talking to each other.  As they forgive each other, there are a couple of intense sex scenes.  While I was reading it, I was little impatient with the mystery solving - wanting more time with the relationship.  But on hindsight, the mystery solving was ok.  I really liked the action scenes.  My favorite scenes were a sniper shooting at someone and an attack in a parking lot.I would have liked seeing Tucker's feelings and point of view about their past and at other times.  The story is told in third person from Elliot's perspective.Sex scenes include anal.  There are two short scenes where Elliot is remembering or dreaming.  There is a hot kissing scene.  And then there are two longer scenes at about  of the way through which are passionate and tender.POSSIBLE SPOILERS - UNANSWERED QUESTIONS  (I DON'T give away whodunit):There are some things I would have liked explained.  Where did the killer put the dead bodies?  Why did he put one of them in the place it was found and not with the others?  Did he kill men and women or just men?  What did he do with the bodies during the time he had them - before he disposed of them?  Were they dead, alive, drugged?  I wanted to know how the killer first attacked and subdued his victims.  Did he use a knife, gun, rope?  The only one I know about had him wrestling the victim with a hypodermic needle in his hand.DATA:Kindle count story length: 4052.  Swearing language: moderate, including religious swear words.  Sexual language: moderate.  Number of sex scenes: 5.  Setting: current day Tacoma and Puget Sound area in Washington State.  Copyright: 2010.  Genre: gay male mystery suspense romance.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I've read a couple of Josh Lanyon's short stories and enjoyed them quite a lot and so bought this one the other day to try.  I loved it.  It was action packed and suspenseful and Elliot and Tucker obviously had some unresolved issues that needed dealing with.I loved the story and the suspense.  The antagonist was camouflaged pretty well, I thought, and what a sick sick person it was, too.  And it gave Elliot and Tucker not only a reason and the chance to work together again, but also to remember that they were good together before Elliot's injury.  And I loved the interaction between Elliot and Tucker.  It's obvious that they cared about one another, even through the anger and hurt.  They're good for each other - even if it did take a while for them to figure it out.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: This is an excellent mystery with romance on the side.  This is one of Josh's well plotted mysteries, well written and not obvious.  The characters are engaging and real.  There is enough romance to satisfy the romantics without swallowing the mystery.Definitely one to read over again.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: This is probably going to sound weird, but I love Lanyon's sentences. The way they bind together so easily and the way they still keep surprising you. It's so delightful and witty - from the very first page of the book. This book made me chuckle and laugh so many times. One of the things I like about Lanyon's books is actually the fact that the story begins right away from the first page in full gear.The mystery part of Fair Game was very clever: there were so many possible suspects. I changed my mind about the murderer at least half a dozen times as the story proceeded! I also like the way some of Lanyon's books have titles with multiple meanings - just like Fair Game did.The chemistry between Elliot and Tucker was titillating and intense. I absolutely love how Lanyon's characters feel so real and imperfect in their actions. These guys weren't neither perfect nor one-dimensional for sure! I genuinely enjoyed the way they argued and the way their logic and squabble twisted and turned and held so many emotions in both sides. All the awkward moments between the main couple were so tangible it almost hurt! These guys fit together so badly that it was impossibly hot, annoying and totally enjoyable. It also was very interesting how in the beginning of the book it looked like that it was Elliot who had been dumped, but when the story continues we find out that both men had been pretty lost at the time of their separation. And the scapegoat Tucker proves to be a very emotional and endearing sweetheart.I did love the sex scenes in this book. The actual sex happens long after a fabulous kiss-in-the-car-scene and an ultra-passionate scene by/in the lake after Elliot gets shot. Those scenes, the extreme tension between the main couple and Elliot's memories about him and Tucker together worked like a sweet, long foreplay.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: A RIVETING, EXCITING, TOUR DE FORCE AND PRETTY DAMN SEXY!
completeRevs.reviewText: I read this about a year ago and was pretty sure it was one of the best Josh Lanyon books I'd read so far. Now, with some other authors under my belt, I decided to see if I was correct.Elliot Mills is a former FBI field agent and with his sometime partner Lance Tucker they had been opposites in their methods but very compatible in the sack. That is, until a disabling injury during a takedown gave Elliot two choices: a desk job with the department or a professorship at a local college. Deciding on the latter meant the end of his relationship, although that had its problems as well.Now, seventeen months later, settled in at his new job at the university, Elliot is again pulled into an investigation of a missing student by the boy's family. He decides to help and as luck would have it, the lead agent from the FBI assigned to the case is none other than Lance.The tension, professional and sexual is evident, with neither willing to admit the underlying need for mutual assistance. With Elliot, like a pit bull, not wanting to let go of the case, and another victim going missing, it seems that Agent Tucker will have to team once again with him.The interplay between the two is fun to watch, the rekindling of their relation is smoking hot, and the steady and swift pace of the investigation is just icing on the cake.This is a thoroughly enjoyable outing for the reader, with a great, intense, and sexy storyline. The conclusion had me turning pages quickly, and when then perpetrator is unmasked, it was a total surprise.I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS, NOT AS JUST A JOSH LANYON BOOK, BUT AS A TERRIFIC READ WITH A HANDS DOWN SMASHING ENDING!  GREAT!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: The characters were likeable for the most part. The sex scenes were a little out of touch with reality and stereotypical.  I didn't really feel the romance. I thought that it was an okay book. It was worth reading but somehow I think this book will become one of the many "ok" books that I read and have forgotten. Still it wasn't terrible. I do like these types of books for the most part but they usually end predictably the same way.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: Intriguing reading with love added into the mix
completeRevs.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book with suspense. Much because it was not all only about the sex. Actually it was little of that and much more about emotions. Elliot is the person we get to know. He is the one, although still told in 3rd person, who tells the story. He had been injured in line of duty some months ago and had lost not only much of his ability to move (and thus he choose to leave his position with FBI), but also the man he cared about. Once again a case of lack of communication. Both men thought the other didn't care enough and not willing to fix the problem.The backdrop of this story about a relationship is disappearance of a student from the university where Elliot is currently professor. The boy is son of Elliot’s father’s friends and thus Elliot gets involved. He has obviously still the abilities that made him a good FBI agent, because he connects the dots and against all odds unravels a serial killer that until now had sailed under the radar.The search for the missing student evolves into game of life and death. Something that brings Elliot and Tucker closer and even if the communication still is not what it should be, they seem to be able to mend their relationship and find their way forward – together (I did not spoil too much, did I?).

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: Many times I thought I had figured things out... but every time I was wrong.The romance in this story is very mild. I like more spice and emotions in the books I read. This book is great if you care more about the adventure of the story. Not so great if you like deep connections between characters.3.5 stars

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I simply fell in love with Mr. Lanyon's writing when i read his Adrien English Mystery series and when I saw this new release from him on NetGalley I just jumped at the chance to read it.Elliot Mills is an ex-FBI who has turned back to his original job of History Professor after a shooting gone wrong left him with a bummed knee almost an year and a half ago.He lives by himself, doesn't really have a social life and hasn't dated ever since his not so amicable break up with former colleague and FBI agent Tucker Lance over an year before.Tucker and Elliot get thrown together when Elliot's father asks him to look into the disappearance of a student of his university and since the kid's father is high profile, the FBI is in charge of the case and Tucker is the agent on the job.Fair game is a great character driven romantic thriller. The plot and whodunit mystery is definitely more prominent than the romance, but you can't help but root for Elliot and Tucker to make it work and just admit that what they once had was much more than casual and that they can work together in the future.I LOVE Tucker! He is a hard-ass federal agent, but he is also lovable and not afraid to say he is wrong and to fight for what he wants. His and Elliot's relationship only works out because he is willing to put in the extra mile and let go of his pride.Elliot is a great leading man and I think i like him more because he was flawed. He made me want to punch him whenever he was being stubborn, but I definitely understood his reticence and difficulty in letting go. He and Tucker make such a cute and lovable couple, you can't help but swoon.The mystery in Fair Game is pretty awesome and I found myself trying to guess who was the perpetrator and being wrong all the time, I ended up getting it right right before Elliot and I felt that it was perfect. It didn't make me feel stupid and it also didn't make me feel smarter than the main character.All in all Fair Game is a fast-paced character driven romantic thriller featuring two very swoon worthy men and creepy mystery that will keep you on your toes. If you love a good whodunit and are into an awesome m/m romance that does not overshadow the over all story, this is the book for you.Originally Posted at Welcome to Larissa's Bookish Life {larissaslife DOT com}

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: The beginning seemed to drag along for a while but it slowly gathered momentum. It is as much a thriller as a love story. As for the protagonists, one is an FBI agent who has a love/hate/love relationship with an ex-FBI agent turned college professor who together try to find a serial killer.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: Josh Lanyon is on my must-buy list, so I was surprised when I got my new Kindle that for some reason I had missed this book when it was first published. I am glad I bought it now, because late is better than nothing.Premise: Elliott, is a retired FBI agent who after being injured on the job has taken up teaching at a small university. When a friend of the family's son disappears, the boy's parents ask Elliott to look into the matter. This brings him back into contact with his ex-FBI partner (and lover) Tucker. Their relationship at the beginning is strained to say the least. As the novel progresses and more young men have gone missing, Elliott and Tucker soon realize they have a serial killer on their hands whose man goal is to torment Elliott. The question is will Tucker and Elliott stop this mad man or will his game end with the death of one (or both) of them?I love Lanyon's mysteries. Some of the time I can figure out the killer, and sometimes I cannot. "Fair Game" was one of those novels where the person who I thought was the serial killer wasn't and the person who was the killer wasn't even on my suspect list! That takes true talent as I was raised on Agatha Cristie and Sherlock Holmes novels. The love story between Elliott and Tucker felt real, not forced and even though there was originally a Big Misunderstanding about why they broke up originally, their reunion made sense. Plus the secondary characters (some suspects) were three dimensional and complex, as always with Josh's books. All in all, this was a very enjoyable read. I highly recommend it.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewerName: LAS Reviewer "The Long and the Short Of It Re...
completeRevs.summary: You Need to Read This Book
completeRevs.reviewText: Originally posted at: [...]Fair Game by Josh Lanyon is a finely crafted mystery that keeps you guessing until the very end who the killer is, but most important, if Elliot and Tucker will live happily ever after.Elliot Mills does not realize how much he misses his past life as an FBI agent until he agrees to help a family friend find his missing son. His investigation finds him working with ex-lover Tucker Lance, and he discovers their relationship is far from over. As Elliot finds himself in the crosshairs of the killer and in protective custody, he and Tucker are finally forced to take a closer look at what drove them apart.Fair Game is more than a fast paced mystery. It is a journey of self-discovery for Elliot as he reconciles himself to his new life as a college professor and as he works to resolve his relationship with Tucker.The past relationship between Elliot and Tucker was intense and short-lived due to his injury, recovery, and subsequent departure from the FBI. It was apparent they had many unresolved issues, and Mr. Lanyon does not rush their reconciliation. Surprisingly enough, Tucker is the one who opens up and takes those first crucial steps toward salvaging their relationship. While Elliot has excellent social skills for handling superficial relationships, he often finds himself at a loss in dealing with the deeper relationships with Tucker and to some extent, his father, Roland. When he finds himself in danger of losing both relationships, he does not hesitate to take a hard look at himself and work to fix what is broken.Mr. Lanyon's characters are exceptionally well-developed, realistic, and three dimensional. Some of the best scenes in Fair Game are between Elliot and Roland. The two men are polar opposites and many of their interactions are laugh out loud funny. The glimpses into the academic life of a college professor are interesting and accurate. While there are plenty of suspects to choose from, Mr. Lanyon keeps the killer under wraps until the end, and the reader and Elliot piece it together at the same time.Fair Game by Josh Lanyon is a delightful mix of mystery, love, and humor. This is my first Josh Lanyon book but I can guarantee it will not be my last.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I LOVED this book! I love pretty much anything Josh Lanyon writes, but this one was just fantastic! This book should be sold as a mainstream mystery/thriller. It's really sad that it won't be simply because the protagonist is gay. But the fact that Elliot is gay is really rather beside the point. It's a real credit to Josh Lanyon's writing skill and style that you feel you're not reading about a gay relationship (when it comes to his relationship with Tucker - which is not the main thrust of the story, but still vital), but just a relationship. You get so involved with Elliot, the person, and his prickly relationship with Tucker, that you don't think along the lines of it being gay vs. straight. It just IS. I love that. Josh always has the ability to draw characters so vividly, so realistically, you start to feel you know them. You really feel a connection and start to care about them. The characters in this book, especially Elliot, are no different.The story here, though...the mystery is what draws you in. You get sucked into the story from the beginning, and it doesn't let you go until you reach the end. I was truly surprised once the culprit was revealed. When I first read this, (I'm about to start reading it again for the third time.) I was still in physical therapy after a couple of knee surgeries. So, I really felt a connection to the pain Elliot was experiencing with his knee (though, mine couldn't compare to his practically being shot off!). Josh is a master of writing in the first person. He did it to perfection in the Adrien English books, and he does so here as well. You get an insight into a character like no other with this writing format. You feel what the character feels, you see what the character sees, and you experience things right along with the character. When reading this book, you understand just how much Elliot misses being an FBI agent. You feel his heartache at knowing that the career he loved is over. You feel his abivalence at being a college professor. You feel his resurrected joy and energy at delving into helping to solve the mystery of the missing students. You feel Elliot's hurt, anger, tension, and a deeper emotion he's not ready to admit is love when he meets up with Tucker again.There are some chilling moments, too. You get creeped out when Elliot comes home to his cabin and suspects he's not alone. You're willing Elliot to hurry up and get back to his car when he's on the college campus at night alone, retracing the steps of one of the missing students. And the ending...when you realize (I won't give away any details) at the same time what Elliot is realizing, when he's at the gala event and looking at...Well, you'll have to read it to find out. It's very chilling! I highly, highly recommend this book! I really hope Josh plans on a sequel!

There were multiple possibilities for the killer and although i had my suspicions I really wasn't totally sure until the end.Even though the author chose not to include an epilogue and ended the book very quickly (my biggest pet peeve) I still have to go 5 stars. completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: This was my first introduction to Josh Lanyon, and I was instantly hooked to his writing and his characters. This is a solid murder mystery that kept me guessing right to the end, and the characters are compelling and real. It's not often I read books that make me root for characters, much less want to strangle of couple of former hippies (one more than the other), but this one had me emotionally invested on what was going to happen next. One of the things I enjoy most about JL's books is that he tends to give the main character some sort of physical limitation, and he details it so well as to make it believable and easy to identify with that character, and thus make you root for them more. I've re-read it once already and enjoyed it even more the second time around, a sure sign of a great book.

The love scenes were tastefully portrayed,with the romance foremost and riveting. I fell in love with both of the heroes, and was delighted when theyresolved their differences and got their HEA.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I love a good mystery and this book had a great one along with just the right amount of romance! Loved it!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: The most difficult reviews to write are for the books I really liked, because it's hard to analyze what left an emotion, so I must write a review based on impressions rather than on rational, critical thoughts.First of all, I'll never stop being impressed by Mr Lanyon's writing, it's at the same time a real pleasure and a never-ending surprise. I can't count the number of times I had to re-read a paragraph or a few lines of dialogue because they were too good.I liked the cast of characters. I enjoyed the way Elliot and Tucker were forced to meet again and how their first conversations seemed like the tip-toeing of elephants. It's always fascinating to watch estranged people who have to interact again (even if it's usually painful), because the intimacy they had is undeniable and it can't be suppressed and the situation was rendered beautifully.We had only Elliot's point of view, so we were closer to him, but it's Elliot who, at one point, acknowledges Tucker's reason for the way he behaved after Elliot's injury. The honesty and understanding made me feel an incredible admiration for him (and he's a fictional character!)I also liked the mistery. At one point I was so sure I had the murderer! Big surprise there and I'm not referring to whom the killer was, but to whom he wasn't, if it makes sense.5 star. I hope Elliot and Tucker will return. Please!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: In Josh Lanyon's riveting, gay-themed mystery, "Fair Game" former FBI agent and now current history professor, Elliot Mills, finds himself wrapped up in solving the case of a missing boy, who is a student at a private Washington university where Elliot teaches. Because of his history as a Special Agent, Pauline Baker, the mother of the disappeared student, Terry Baker asks for Elliot's help in gathering clues as to the whereabouts of her missing son. Elliot reluctantly agrees to do so, only because Pauline is a family friend. Coincidentally, Elliot's former boyfriend, Tucker Lance is also assigned to Terry Baker's case, which stirs up resentful memories for Elliot, who despite his anger toward the hard-edged Tucker, is still attracted to him. As Elliot becomes more involved in the case, as well as the similar disappearance of another male student, Elliot himself becomes the target of a killer's vile cat and mouse game.Lanyon is superb at creating compelling, believable, and fully realized characters. Readers automatically connect with Elliot, a former FBI agent, who bitterly had to resign his position, after a brutal altercation with an assailant years ago left him with a severely damaged knee and the incapability to work in the field. Lanyon does a good job at illustrating Eliot's plight over the mundane routine of being a college professor and wishing he was still an agent. It does not help that his former lover Tucker is involved with the case, which means that Elliot is forced to interact with him, even though he does not want to. Lanyon also does a good job with the verbal matches between Elliot and Tucker. Both are strong, stubborn men, almost incapable of lowering their emotional guards and yet are irresistibly drawn to each other. It's very interesting to see the dynamic of their interactions change though the course of the novel, as the danger becomes more real.What makes "Fair Game" really work is that it really is a mystery. I've noticed in a lot of gay-themed mysteries, the stories are really just thinly-veiled romances with a very easily solvable mystery thrown in. "Fair Game" is actually a really involving, detailed, and intelligent mystery that will you really keep you guessing. Another thing that really shines about this book is the suspense works two ways: the reader is urgent to find out the identity of the villain (who was pretty surprising) and also the suspense of Elliot and Tucker's reconciliation. If you're looking for a good mystery, "Fair Game" is a great pick.Michael S. BookerAuthor of "Anomaly

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: Professor Elliot Mills used to be an FBI agent. He likes teaching, but doesn't hesitate to get back into action when a student disappears and the case seems suspicious. Elliot's ex-lover, FBI Agent Tucker Lance, is working the case and doesn't want Elliot around, regardless of his experience. Elliot and Tucker find it difficult to be in the same room together after how badly their relationship ended, but soon Elliot's making more progress than anyone else on the case. As Elliot and Tucker try to make peace with their past, Elliot becomes the killer's next target.While I do masochistically enjoy the angsty romantic hell Josh Lanyon usually puts me through while reading his books, Fair Game has a little less gut wrenching heartache than his norm, and I loved it just as much. Lanyon has the expert ability to write realistic, suspenseful tales. Countless times throughout Fair Game I found myself pegging the villain only to realize I was mistaken yet again. The plot is not contrived or obtrusive, and it kept me riveted to each intriguing page. Along with an exciting storyline, Fair Game stars two very appealing men. Excellent characterization brings Tucker and Elliot to life. Despite the fact that Elliot is a professor now, he's a detective at heart and he plays that role amazingly well. He and Tucker make a terrific crime fighting team. Tucker has regrets, except his pride gets in the way of making things right. While they have a lot in common and are compatible in and out of the bedroom, it's that same common ground that causes strife between them. Sex between Elliot and Tucker is hard, hot, and meaningful, but it's not the focal point of their story. Fair Game is a novel of suspense with well-penned eroticism. It's the next great story in Josh Lanyon's arsenal of well-written gay suspense novels.NannetteReviewed

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I enjoyed this book so much.  It had the romance, (I am all about romance), the suspense, the humor, the action...  Everything necessary for a good read and it provided a deep insight into all the characters thoughts and motives.  So often when you get toward the end of a book it seems as if an author gets tired of writing and does what they must to wrap it up.  Not this one.  This was one of the most exciting final chapters of a book that I have ever read!  I peeked at about halfway through to see who the killer was, because ahem, studies show that spoilers improve your comprehension of the material.  Yep.  But you will enjoy it either way. I am off to look at other books by this author now.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.summary: Perfect blend of Mystery and Romance
completeRevs.reviewText: Josh has woven a thriller that grabs the reader and does not let go until the end.Not only is the book full of suspense with the right balance of romance, but it is also well-plotted (as expected) and loaded with plenty of mis-direction. You also are introduced to another terrific bunch of characters. I adored Elliot, Tucker, Roland and their complicated relationships.Fair Game draws the reader in with the picturesque setting of Puget Sound, the tense/scary nature of the plot and the author's beautiful, evocative prose (as usual). But it is the book's characters, their relationships, and the mystery that unfolds that make this work a standout.  Waiting for a sequel!....Highly Recommended!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: This was the second time I've read this book. Shamefully, I remembered nothing but the beatnik dad - he refers to way too many men as "cat" not to remember him - and that it had a generally happy ending. Clearly I read way too many books last year if I forgot a Josh Lanyon novel. I read 537 books in 2013 and I'm pretty sure that's a low estimation. I know, it's a sickness.Here’s another sickness: Why do I feel a sense of pride that Elliot was shot, in the rain, at Pioneer Courthouse Square, in Portland, Oregon? I should be a tour guide – that’s right, folks, Portland is so great FBI agents get shot here too! And in such a pretty area! Isn’t that wonderful! Followed by: Hometown pride, GO….oh that’s right, we don’t have a sports team. But we do have some very tall trees.This section of the review is entitled: Elliot Mills, you giant sack of poo.Elliot, buddy, I mean it sincerely when I say I love you but if you say there’s nothing but sex (and Nissans) between you & Tucker one more time, I’m planning on borrowing the nearest penis & making violent love to him myself. You ask yourself, "how the hell could you be homesick for a place that had never been home?" Um, cause you love him? Cause he is your home? Maybe? DUR. You seem to come to your senses by the end of the novel, but I’ve got my eye on you, buddy. (Seriously, though, I lurve you.) And ease up on all the Civil War music; that cannot possibly be healthy for anyone.This section is entitled: Tucker Lance, I want to climb your horny gingerness like a howler monkey.You make my down-belows sparkle. That’s pretty much it.To both boys: Communication is not just for cry baby pee-pants anymore, ok?That’s right, adults do it too. Listen to teacher now….Elliot, you should learn by watching Tucker. He may be a tough FBI agent who sucks all the air of any room he enters (with his utter ginger hotness), but he’s clearly willing to open up and share his feelings with you. Even if it takes another near death incident and about 75% of the book for him to do it. However, this is something you both need to work on. Like Dr. Phil says, do you want to be right or do you want to be happy? Something to think about, hmm? Dismissed.That said, Josh Lanyon is fantastic at portraying a serious lack of communication. It’s something I find intensely annoying when done by some (many) authors, because it generally goes something like: "Hey, dude, I really need to expl—oh, look. The vampires are attacking again." They’re just simple minded distractions created by an author to keep heroes apart. They have no actual meaning beyond extending an already weak novel. Lanyon creates two strong-willed men who are afraid to openly communicate, afraid of the answers they might hear. Like Adrien says in "Death of a Pirate King." "I just didn’t ask the questions I didn’t want to know the answers to."Another thing Lanyon does well? Sexy sex sex. Thank you, Mr. Lanyon, for not adding the ever popular “I need to stroke my ding dong in the shower cause I’m thinking about my one true love & the author thinks it’s way too early for us to get it on.” Instead we get ha-ta-ta-tot-hot dreams & memories of sex with Tucker: "He kept remembering the weird, unlikely pleasure of being rolled onto his face and being [made violent love to] to within an inch of his sanity by someone bigger and stronger and possibly even hornier than himself." I WANT TO GO TO THERE.My favorite part of the book is the juxtaposition of the investigation of Elliot and Tucker’s feelings for each other and the investigation into the disappearance of two young college students. Elliot, Tucker and the reader spend the novel wondering what happened to these young men. Did they just take off and abandon their loved ones? Or was it something more sinister? Similarly Elliot and Tucker scrutinize their own feeling for each other – both feel abandoned by the other. Both feel that the other disappeared from their lives. Elliot, especially, uses the investigation as a way to explore the loss of his previous life and whether the end of that life means the end of his relationship with Tucker.I still have several questions about the mystery though. Which I can't list here without ticking people off about spoilers.I’m giving this book a very solid 4.25 stars, rounded down to 4. This is an excellent novel and I highly recommend it…but for me it didn’t hold that gut-punch of recognition I felt for the Adrien English series. Now that I’ve read that, I’m afraid every Josh Lanyon book will have to compete with it for first place in my heart.

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: Bought it and read it within the same day. Could not put it down once I started. Love the mystery with its depth and well thought out plot. Never suspect the villain as the mystery evolves into something more sinister which I never anticipated. As for Elliot and Tucker, these 2 guys really grow on you. Equally alpha males, these two complex characters really have to work out their misunderstandings, wariness and trust but not before some explosive exchanges. Josh has expressed the romance angle so well even if the mystery is the focus. As another reviewer says, Fair Game is indeed a perfect blend of mystery and romance. As in any Josh's book, sex is kept to the right balance which I highly appreciate. And I also enjoy the interaction between father and son. The gritty ending has me holding my breath. And like another reviewer (Sirius) says I love it that Josh gives more closure to the guys' commitment to each other and not leave it to our imagination. Not that I am complaining but I just want to enjoy it in words. Highly recommended and waiting most impatiently for Josh's next effort!

completeRevs.title: Fair Game
completeRevs.reviewText: I've not read Josh Lanyon in a while, so this was a cool pick up. I always enjoy Josh's deft plotting and smart characters. In Fair Game he's created an ex cop who is forced to give up a career he's loved and take up a more desk bound job. The dynamics between Eliott and his lover Tucker were pretty tense and steamy, although at times I wished Tucker was featured a little more prominently. I think the focus was more on Elliot's journey and the mysterious disappearance of the young men, kinda like his scooby swan song. Cool read and worth checking out.

He  writes thoroughly believable characters , with depth and  intelligence, The  fact that  they are  gay is  ancillary.  the  romance  portion of the story is  also  in line  with  reality, lying  in  actual male parallels.  The  mystery in the stories  is convincing, convoluted , and  for once I  am  left  wondering  who  the  culprit is.
